title.narrative: Support Justice Reform, Enhance the Rule of Law, Develop Human Rights and Strengthen Institutions - JEDI

description.narrative: The project seeks to strengthen democratic governance and rule of law in Tunisia by 1) improving access to justice by increasing awareness of rights among citizens; 2) accompanying the justice sector reform by contributing to the development of legal frameworks and justice institutions; 3) supporting the protection of human rights by strengthening respective institutional mechanisms; and 4) fostering inclusive and accountable democratic governance processes. The different components are designed to be mutually reinforcing.

mailing-address.narrative: 12 bis, Rue du Lieutenant Bejaoui Menzah 5 2091 Ariana Tunisie

policy-marker.narrative: Gender equality is a fundamental aspect of DRI’s mission to promote democracy. In our view, equality is an integral part of democracy, including for all genders, religious, ethnic, and socio-economic groups, and people of different ages and abilities. DRI commits to a gender-sensitive approach and to mainstreaming gender issues in all aspects of our projects. In line with UN Resolution 132514 and SDG 5, and to ensure that DRI’s projects are designed, implemented and evaluated in a gender-sensitive manner, we have introduced a gender and diversity policy and a gender mainstreaming tool which is applied across our offices worldwide. This activity will therefore place special emphasis on gender and diversity by ensuring the equal participation of women and vulnerable groups in project activities, and, whenever relevant to the context, emphasizing gender issues.

The overall goal of the activity is to contribute to strengthening democratic governance and the rule of law in Tunisia. This will be achieved holistically through addressing identified constraints and bottlenecks in Tunisia’s democratic transition, namely: 1) the need to increase awareness and knowledge among Tunisian citizens on laws, legal institutions and ways to access them; 2) the need for a number of critical justice system reforms; 3) the need for effective institutional mechanisms to protect human rights along with transparency and accountability; 4) the need to support to participatory democracy, through promoting a more inclusive parliament. By supporting several key stakeholders, including civil society, media, legal and human rights institutions, and the parliament, the activity will create networks and synergies between different actors and interventions, while ensuring that the voices of Tunisian citizens, including the most marginalized, are heard and considered in all processes in line with SDG 16 and SDG 5.

receiver-org.narrative: Final installment of subgrant to KADEM

title.narrative: Proposal of the Activity
Annual Analytical Progress Report I - 2019

condition.narrative: 1) Lawyers continue to be receptive to support from international organisations and have the requisite time to engage in capacity-building trainings 2) The Assembly of People’s Representatives allocates adequate budgetary resources to Supreme Judicial Council and its members are willing and open to pursue cooperation with external partners 3) The Assembly of People’s Representatives allocates adequate budgetary resources to Human Rights Commission and the institution is willing to cooperate with external partners 4) The Assembly of People’s Representatives allocates adequate budgetary resources to Constitutional Court and the institution is open to cooperation with external partners 5) Stakeholders continue to have a cooperative attitude and are willing to engage with the international community and other stakeholder groups

1) Socio-economic situation allows for continued implementation of reforms 2) Security situation remains stable & does not affect the reforms process 3) Continued support by the national authorities of the principles of the independence of a free and fair justice system 4) The authorities remain committed to the reforms and the implementation of the constitution. Stakeholders remain cooperative and determined to carry out the reform 5) Draft law creating the Human Rights Commission is adopted 6) Members of the Constitutional Court are elected, and the Constitutional Court is created and functional
1) Subgrantees are committed to use received funds for the intended purpose and in line with the project objectives.

title.narrative: Institutional mechanisms to protect human rights are strengthened
# of institutional mechanisms implemented by the partners (resulting from strategy documents and action plans)
% supported institutions staff reporting increased performances as a result of DRI's capacity building activities
Increased awareness of rights and use of fair and effective justice systems by citizens from all groups
% of targeted groups reporting an increased knowledge of rights on access to justice
Degree of usefulness of the knowledge products reported by institutional partners
Contribute to the development of legal frameworks and justice institutions, supporting them to perform their tasks independently, fairly, effectively, and accountable, with better coordination
# laws/draft related to the justice sector reform produced with DRI’s support to ensure they are in line with the constitution
# of actions implemented by supported institutions in line with the strategic documents produced
# of institutions supported
Parliament and Civil Society are provided with technical support to develop legislation and to strengthen cooperation mechanisms to engage in dialogue to strengthen mutual cooperation
# of cooperation mechanisms between the Parliament and Civil society that are introduced and /or strengthened
# of recommendations that were taken into consideration in the legislative processes (at different milestones: commission, planary)
More inclusive and accountable democratic governance processes at national and local levels
% Change in Government Effectiveness

description.narrative: Government Effectiveness captures perceptions of the quality of public services, the quality of the civil service and the degree of its independence from political pressures, the quality of policy formulation and implementation, and the credibility of the government's commitment to such policies

title.narrative: % Change in Civil Society Participation

description.narrative: This indicator captures the extent to which the government enables the participation of civil society in the political process; allows NGOs to organise freely and involves civil society actors in the political process; and does not persecute or harass NGO employees.

title.narrative: Strengthened democratic governance and rule of law in Tunisia
State legitimacy

description.narrative: The State Legitimacy Indicator considers the representativeness and openness of government and its relationship with its citizenry. The Indicator looks at the population’s level of confidence in state institutions and processes, and assesses the effects where that confidence is absent, manifested through mass public demonstrations, sustained civil disobedience, or the rise of armed insurgencies

title.narrative: % Change in Citizen Participation & Public Accountability performance

description.narrative: Voice and Accountability captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media

title.narrative: Strengthened rule of law so the citizens are better able to access their right through fair, efficient, impartial, independent, and accountable institutions
% Change in Rule of Law performance

description.narrative: Rule of Law captures perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence

title.narrative: % Change in Human Rights performance

description.narrative: Freedom in the World assess the condition of political rights and civil liberties. It analyzes the electoral process, political pluralism and participation, the functioning of the government, freedom of expression and of belief, associational and organizational rights, the rule of law, and personal autonomy and individual rights.
